captions.text: Good morning Hank, it's Tuesday.

So when we think of Africa, we often think
of it as one place, right? You know, it's

this poor, disease-ridden continent where
people live in thatched-roof huts and children

don't get good educations, and then there's
like a tiny wealthy elite, most of whom wear

overly decorous military uniforms, smoke cigars,
and laugh about all of the aid that they're
embezzling.
But yeah, no.

For one thing, Africa isn't just one place.
Most Canadians live closer to Venezuela than

Liberians live to Botswana. But for another,
those stereotypes are just ridiculous. I mean,

I did meet a lot of people who live in thatched-roof
huts in Ethiopia and a lot of children who

didn't have access to good schools, and corruption
remains a significant problem, BUT just as

Ethiopia's poverty rate is falling, its middle
class is rising. More and more kids go to

primary school, and the main university in
Addis Ababa which in 1950 had thirty-two students

today has more than 42,000. And when I was
in Ethiopia I got to meet a bunch of them

with Bill Gates including this young woman,
Meheret, who started an anti-domestic violence
initiative.

[Meheret:] Basically a group of volunteers
that, uh, that want to see a better community

and that want to see a better country and
a better society so we bas—so we work on
gender and race violence.

[John:] So yeah, Ethiopia has anti-domestic
violence activists and insurance agents and
web developers and nurses and etcetera.

Okay Hank, I want to give you a sense of some
of these students, like these two young women

are pre-med, and they talked a lot about the
risks and opportunities of working abroad.

[Pre-med student:] There are so many brilliant
minds going to the Western countries and,
you know, they won't come back.

[John:] The other students were future engineers
and lawyers and a couple people who weren't

sure what they wanted to do yet. You know,
like me in college.

I waited until like three minutes into the
conversation before I asked if they watched
Youtube.
[John:] Do—do you watch videos on Youtube?
[Student:] Yeah.
[John:] For fun, or for school?
[Student:] For fun and for school.

[John:] Hank, for fun AND for school?! These
people are nerdfighters if ever I have seen
one.

But this brings up an interesting problem,
which is that the internet in Ethiopia is

CRAZY SLOW. [Dial-up modem noise plays] I
mean, like, yes, that slow. That makes it

hard to watch a lot of creators, it makes
it hard to comment; it also takes forever

for Tumblr to load. And we talked about how
that makes it hard to be an active participant

in online communities. Almost all of their
social media interaction happens with people

they know in real life. To which I said, "What
is real life??"

It was also interesting to talk to them about
platforms. Like, I asked this future engineer
what what social media he uses…

[Future engineer:] Facebook not as much now.
I'm more going to Twitter now.

[John:] That's right, Hank. College students
all over the world are so over Facebook.

Also, just like I hear from a lot of American
students, these students felt a lot of tension

between, like, what they dreamt of doing and
what they'd been told they should do. Although

in their case it wasn't just about parental
wishes or future job opportunities, there
was also a kind of larger sense of responsibility.

[Future engineer:] Something is expected from
you in terms of what your country really needs
now.

[John:] And I also heard a lot of concern,
which I'm sure some nerdfighters can relate

to, that book-learning might not translate
to real-world success.

[Student:] You know, I got A+ on different
subjects. I know how to do integrations. But
how can I just express that in reality?

[John:] Hank I think we have to pause quickly
here just to note the astonishing zit on the

side of my neck. Are you sentient, zit? Do
you have a soul?

Anyway, so after meeting with these students,
I went to the library's bathroom, where there

was a bucket full of water that you had to
pour into the tank in order to make the toilet

flush because there is no running water in
the library.

Hank, there isn't just one Ethiopia. The college
library with no water is Ethiopia, but these

future engineers who will build the city's
infrastructure are also Ethiopia. These kids

are Ethiopia, and so is this doctor, and so
are these farmers, and so is this presidential

marching band. Now I know that when we see
Africa on the news or in the movies it's always

like "War! Pirates! Refugees! Disease!" But
the stories I saw in Ethiopia were far more

complicated and ultimately more compelling.
These remarkable young people have seen the

greatest drops in poverty rates and infant
mortality in their country's history, but

every year in Ethiopia, tens of thousands
of children still die of easily-preventable

diseases. And if we've learned one thing from
Global health in the last twenty years, it's

that if those kids don't die, and they don't
have to, then they can grow up and end up
studying in that library.
I'll see you on Friday.

On Africa: Don't generalise. 30 million sq km, 1.2 billion human beings 
(sorry, the populations are still rising but the resources and land are 
not). One thing that continent needs (badly) is population control. Without 
it, it will remain more or less in poverty and lorded over by wealthy 
elites. Poor people have more kids and that is of no doubt going to broaden 
the wealth gap﻿

comments.text:
Hello John, as an Ethiopian who was born and raised in Ethiopia, I would 
like to thank you for making this video. This video will help enlighten 
people who have been fed the wrong information about my country and 
continent. And what made me even more happy was reading the comments 
written by people who have been describing how this video opened their 
eyes. Some non Ethiopians know more about my country than i do which 
restores my faith in the west. Thank you brother.﻿
comments.author: Besufekad Azage

comments.text:
While I appreciate that Africa is a complicated place with complicated 
problems, I also think that is true of nearly every problem people 
encounter. I love that John is focusing on Africa and raising awareness to 
help those countries, I think that the fact that it's complicated applies 
to so much that it shouldn't be the final note of so many of these videos. 
Also, this is probably just because I've been watching these in rapid 
succession trying to get caught up﻿
comments.author: vexbatch

comments.text:
The only Ethiopian I've ever personally met was very different from what I 
expected. One, he didn't LOOK African to me. He was fairly light-skinned 
and looked more like someone from Southwest Asia. Two, he was not exactly 
skinny. Three, he came from a very wealthy family. My understanding is that 
his father was in some kind of position of power and they had to flee the 
country when that power was being overturned. The only stereotypical thing 
about him was that he was petrified of my little dog.

Anyway, he was a really nice guy and it was very eye-opening to meet a 
wealthy person from the country whose name has always been synonymous with 
poverty in my mind.﻿

comments.author: bianca gonzalez

comments.text:
Let me try to give insight on the middle class of Ethiopia. I lived there 
for nine years, as a middle class citizen, in a rather well developed part 
of the city. Yes, we have supermarkets, where else could we get our 
groceries? I also lived in the Bole area, so I was within about a mile 
radius of at least seven different malls. Ten or more of you extended it to 
two miles. Yes, the malls were "proper", we even had a cinema which showed 
all the new releases. There was a bookstore where I could buy the Harry 
Potter books about two weeks after their release. My closest encounter with 
wildlife was at the zoo. My point is, the middle class is not so different. 
Apart from poverty being prevalent and such.﻿
comments.author: Mary Yilma

comments.text:
John, this video is extremely bias. Of course, people know that Ethiopia 
has an elite class. What country doesn't? Yes, there might be development 
there but you have to look at what expense do these changes come at. Right 
now, there's a movement to replace the Oromo and  Anuak farmers from their 
way of life in the name of development. Meles Zenawi, the former president, 
is blamed for mass extinction of Oromo defenders. There's tons of human 
rights violations taking place in Ethiopia. Free speech isn't afforded to 
dissidents. Bloggers have been arrested for voicing their opinions and 
oppositions to the current government. ﻿
comments.author: inquisitive871

comments.text: Meles Zenawi was the prime minister not president.

comments.text:
Africa is a Continent with some 54 countries just like Europe and the 
others.. what makes Ethiopia unique from other African countries?

- It is the birth place of Humanity (..the first ape started walking 
upright in Ethiopia)
- The only African country never to have been colonized by European
- The only African country which has managed to defeat Colonial power 
(Italy)
- A well documented history dating back to over 3,000 years 
- The birth place of Coffee (..remembered Starbucks?)
- The only African country with its own Scripts still in use, a Calendar 
and Time system

What about now...

- one of the fastest growing economy in Africa 
- operates the most successful airline with the second largest fleet next 
to SA
- In seven years, it has become one of the four largest economies in Africa
.... just run out of time ... have to go..﻿

been to africa. surprisingly, 25% of the class raised their hand. So the 
volunteers asked where we've been to. the answers? Egypt, Egypt, Libya,

needless to say, the volunteer group made themselves look like a bunch of

comments.author: Roderick Daniels

comments.text:
A great (and short - 4 minutes) video from writer and nerdfighter 
extraordinaire John Green about "the diversity and complexity of 
contemporary Ethiopia."

We all tend to hear a lot more about things like climate change, the 
middle-east, china, and so on, but Africa is like, really really really 
really important!! To everything!!  For those of us who grew up in the 
eighties during the Ethiopian famine, our image of the country probably was 
very much formed during that time. It's not entirely a false image, by any 
means, but it does need to be expanded on. 

Another African country I find really interesting, and which is changing 
extraordinarily rapidly, is Kenya: 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenya#Vision_2030﻿

comments.text:
I used to live in Addis Ababa and moved to the US five years ago. My mom 
still lives in Addis. I have to say I miss that place with all my heart. 
 It's kind of ridiculous with all the question I receive on a daily basis. 
The only way to observe that AFRICA is this  unfathomably enormous place is 
by changing one's perspective through education on the region or by 
actually physically going there ( like John Green did). I am still sad that 
many people remain thoughtless and ignorant to the reality that Africa is 
in fact a continent with many estates and regions and people and countless 
cultures. Can't wait to visit it next summer.  By the way, John Green you 
are awesome. ﻿

comments.text:
Hey, I thought you'd like to know that a student in my Humanities class 
shared this video with our professor and she showed it in class and we 
discussed it! They liked what you had to say and agreed with you (for the 
most part). We talked a lot about how many people generalize countries like 
Africa and patriotism and what it means to be patriotic. For example, on of 
the young women you interviewed mentioned how many intelligent people were 
taking their degrees and going to more developed countries, but there is 
such a great need for their skills in their own country, so do you have a 
duty to use your talents to benefit your country? They also thought you 
were hyped up on caffeine. I said no, he's just enthusiastic about what he 
does!﻿

comments.text:
While many of us here in the US of A enjoy many benefits of a good 
education and the ability to go to college, there are still many nations 
where going to college can be difficult at best. John Green, author of "The 
Fault in Our Stars" took a trip with Bill Gates to Ethiopia. They take a 
look at Colleges from this 3rd world nation. You may be surprised by some 
of the reporting and the fluency of the students he interviewed in English 
among some of the obstacles they have to overcome. 
http://youtu.be/UhNXdOaXisU﻿

comments.author: Melat Tarekegne

comments.text:
John, you should write a book where a autistic child is portrayed as being 
able to feel all the same emotions that everyone one else is. I have 
Asperger's syndrome, an autism spectrum disorder, I hate how people with 
autism spectrum disorders are portrayed as being emotionless, never being 
shown as able to love and be loved. I can say, if anyone can, that this is 
just so wrong, I've battled depression, I've been bullied by both students 
and teachers, I have felt all the things teenagers feel, but people don't 
see people with autism this way, simply because they don't express these 
emotions through the same body language and facial expressions that other 
people do. Although I have largely learned how to make eye contact and read 
body language and all those things I am fairly certain other people can 
tell something is different about me. You seem like someone who would write 
a book like this, after reading the fault in our stars I wouldn't be 
surprised is you did write something like this.﻿
comments.author: Edward Kenway

comments.text: Going to College (in Ethiopia): http://youtu.be/UhNXdOaXisU﻿
comments.author: Harry Hawk

comments.text:
Actually... the governments DO steal the aid money lol it's why they still 
don't have running waters and how the small number of rich get to have 
fancy clothes and expensive homes, charity... so i don't advise anyone to 
donate to charities because most of it will go into the rich pockets and 
not to giving the colleges running water... all that money they get and 
they can't afford to give them running water? i find that hard to believe 
lol. You look like you got stung by a huge mozzie or bee lol.

I do not understand why anyone still hope on colleges giving them good 
education though... education these days is a joke... i've constantly been 
let down by education since high school and college was an even bigger 
waste of my time... they are just money making shemes now, what they are 
doing is turning colleges into a buisness and they get the students to run 
them for free while we still pay into the college... for what? since 
clearly they are making tones of money so why are we still paying for our 
courses when we do free labour for them?.

It's led me to the conclusion people are not going to get no where at 
college any more... we all go through the same 1 size fits out education so 
non of us have a different experience... you work hard but the education is 
completely unrealistic. Just like that girl asked "How do you then 
translate it into society?" you can't... lol you just have to be honest 
that you felt that college is rther unrealistic and your looking for a 
chance to work in a realistic environent to work/learn in, id honestly only 
do the basic course and then try to find an internship/apprenticeship 
because doing a degree in unrealistic education isn't going to help you... 
it's why people with degrees these days can't find work.﻿

comments.text:
why am I suddenly proud of the fact that John mentioned my country 
Venezuela? Makes me feel like I exist!  
And also, same thing goes for us, we are not just a jungle, poverty, and an 
oppressive dictatorial government people! You might be surprised to know 
that besides the food, water, electricity and overall safety issues, the 
capital of Venezuela (Caracas), is actually a real city, with sky scrapers, 
malls, highways, and public transportation (including a subway system), and 
the best universities and colleges are public and cost literally pennies 
per month.
You should visit John, there are millions of people here who could use help 
from non profit organizations, but they all seem to think African countries 
are the only ones starving to death.﻿

I think these college students are an excellent example of what charity is 
supposed to accomplish; it helps clear some of the roadblocks for countries 
so that they may prosper. It doesn't really do the heavy lifting. That work 
can only be done by people from the countries. That's why I admire Bill 
Gates and the work done by his foundation so much. They don't see 
themselves as the white saviors selflessly rescuing the poor Africans from 
themselves. They understand that charity is simply one part of the process.﻿

comments.author: Somy Ajeet

comments.text:
Concerning the internet connectivity and/or speed issue in Ethiopia: I'm 
currently living in Addis Ababa, and my family and I have DSL internet at a 
speed of around 1mb/s. Though that may seem like a very slow speed in 
comparison to 1st world countries, it is definitely fast enough to watch 
Youtube videos and much of anything else. Of course a family like ours (we 
are all foreigners in Ethiopia) is the exception to the rule (even most 
foreigners do not have as good of an internet connection as we do). But the 
bottom line is that it is definitely possible to get online in Ethiopia and 
surf the web (For example through 3G internet sticks, which we used to use 
as well).﻿
